Freedom of Religion (Articles 25–28)

Constitutional framework for religious pluralism and secular governance

🧩 Comprehensive Overview

Articles 25-28 establish India's unique model of secularism that:

  • Guarantees individual freedom of conscience and religion
  • Protects collective rights of religious denominations
  • Maintains state neutrality in religious matters
  • Balances religious freedom with public order, health, and morality

Unlike Western secularism that separates religion and state, the Indian model promotes "principled distance" - allowing state intervention to reform religious practices when necessary for social welfare.

📚 Detailed Articles Breakdown

  • Article 25: Freedom of Conscience and Free Profession, Practice and Propagation
    • Applies to both citizens and foreigners
    • Includes right to:
      • Follow any religion (profession)
      • Perform religious rituals (practice)
      • Spread religious beliefs (propagation)
    • Subject to restrictions for:
      • Public order
      • Health
      • Morality
      • Other fundamental rights
    • Allows state regulation of:
      • Economic activities associated with religion
      • Social welfare reforms
  • Article 26: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs
    • Protects rights of religious denominations to:
      • Establish and maintain institutions
      • Manage own affairs in matters of religion
      • Own and acquire property
      • Administer such property
    • Subject to public order, morality and health
  • Article 27: Freedom from Taxation for Religious Purposes
    • Prohibits compulsory taxes for:
      • Promotion/maintenance of any particular religion
    • Permits fees for services rendered (e.g., temple entry fees)
    • Allows state spending for preservation of all religions' heritage
  • Article 28: Freedom from Religious Instruction in State Institutions
    • No religious instruction in wholly state-funded educational institutions
    • Permits in state-recognized/aided institutions with consent
    • Allows religious denominations to maintain their own institutions

✨ Constitutional Significance

These provisions serve crucial functions in India's pluralistic society:

  • Protect minority religions while preventing majority domination
  • Enable social reform of regressive practices (e.g., temple entry movements)
  • Balance individual and collective religious rights
  • Provide framework for resolving inter-religious conflicts
  • Support India's commitment to international human rights instruments

The Supreme Court has described secularism as part of the Constitution's basic structure that cannot be amended.

📜 Historical Context

The freedom of religion provisions draw from multiple influences:

  • Ancient Indian traditions of religious tolerance (Ashoka's edicts)
  • British colonial policies on religious non-interference
  • U.S. First Amendment (Free Exercise Clause)
  • Irish Constitution's religious freedom provisions
  • Post-partition concerns about minority protections

Constituent Assembly debates reveal intense discussions about:

  • Scope of "propagation" rights (Christian missionary concerns)
  • State's power to reform Hindu religious institutions
  • Balancing religious autonomy with social justice

🏛️ Landmark Judicial Interpretations

  • S.R. Bommai v. Union of India (1994) : Established secularism as basic structure of Constitution. [1994 SCC (3) 1]
  • Indian Young Lawyers Association v. State of Kerala (2018) : Allowed women's entry to Sabarimala temple, interpreting religious freedom progressively. [2018 SCC OnLine SC 1690]
  • Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments v. Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar (1954) : Defined "religion" and essential religious practices doctrine. [AIR 1954 SC 282]
  • Stanislaus v. State of Madhya Pradesh (1977) : Distinguished between "propagation" and "forced conversion". [AIR 1977 SC 908]
  • Ismail Faruqui v. Union of India (1994) : Upheld state's power to acquire religious places for national importance. [1994 SCC (6) 360]

🔍 Contemporary Issues

  • Judicial scrutiny of anti-conversion laws
  • Regulation of religious processions and noise pollution
  • Rights of LGBTQ+ persons in religious institutions
  • State intervention in religious management (e.g., temple boards)
  • Online religious hate speech regulation
); }
